holidays.name: National Mimosa Day
holidays.description: A bubbly celebration dedicated to the delightful brunch cocktail combining champagne and chilled orange juice, perfect for a mid-morning pick-me-up!
holidays.origin: Popularized in American brunch culture, the exact origin is unclear but the cocktail dates back to the 1920s in Paris.
holidays.funFact: Mimosas are named after the yellow-flowered mimosa plant because of the cocktail's sunny color!

holidays.name: Wear Purple for Peace Day
holidays.description: A day encouraging people to wear purple as a symbol of peace and unity across the globe, promoting anti-war and anti-violence messages.
holidays.origin: Started by peace activists who chose purple for its symbolism combining calm blue and passionate red.
holidays.funFact: Purple is often used to represent both courage and compassion, making it a perfect color for peace advocacy.

holidays.name: Biographer’s Day
holidays.description: Dedicated to the craft of writing biographies, commemorating the day James Boswell met Samuel Johnson, an iconic event in literary history.
holidays.origin: Honors James Boswell who met Dr. Johnson on May 16, 1763, leading to one of the greatest biographies ever written.
holidays.funFact: Boswell’s detailed account of Johnson’s life set the gold standard for biography writing.

holidays.name: Love a Tree Day
holidays.description: A whimsical day urging people to show appreciation for trees by hugging one, planting one, or simply enjoying their shade.
holidays.origin: Created as an environmental awareness day to foster connection with nature and encourage tree conservation.
holidays.funFact: Tree hugging is not just symbolic—studies suggest physical contact with trees can reduce stress hormones!
